title: Brocade Stole
content:
accession_no_csv: 2016-00336

  Image: 

  object_work_type: scarves (costume accessories) shawls stoles (outerwears)

  title_text: Brocade Stole

  preference: main

  title_language: 

  creation_date: 1801 - 2000

  creation_place_original_location: Varanasi (Uttar Pradesh
 India)

  styles_periods_indexing_terms: Indian (South Asian)

  inscriptions: 

  inscription_language: 

  shape: rectangular

  materials_name: brocade (textile) silk (textile)

  techniques_name: weaving sewing (needleworking technique)

  object_colour: pink colours

  physical_appearance: This brocade stole is predominantly pink in colour
 with a darker shade in the middle and a lighter hue at its sides. It is rectangular in shape. Along its breath
 there are alternating patterns of elephants and birds. Along its length
 there are also elephants and birds
 but in a different form of design and arrangement. Within the borders
 the figure of the Hindu deity Shiva is present all over the brocade stole. The pattern of Shiva is upside down from the top of the stole to its horizontal mid-point. He is in a lotus position and there are patterns of tree branches that come with flowers and parakeets.

  subject_terms_1: textiles (visual works) deities plant-derived motifs motifs Hinduism floral patterns birds (motifs) allover patterns

  subject_terms_2: Textiles Stoles (Clothing) Motifs Siva (Hindu deity) Shawls

  subject_terms_3: Hinduism

  sgcool_label_text: This Benarasi silk brocade carries the extremely unusual motif of Shiva as Yogeshwara
 seated as an ascetic upon a tiger skin
 holding a trident in one hand
 damroo in the other
 which a cobra around his shoulders. Each figure is separated by a flowering plant upon which are perched a magpie and a woodpecker. It is a superb example of the fine detail that Benarasi weavers could achieve using multi-coloured threads and a very tight weave.

metadata.physical_appearance: This brocade stole is predominantly pink in colour, with a darker shade in the middle and a lighter hue at its sides. It is rectangular in shape. Along its breath, there are alternating patterns of elephants and birds. Along its length, there are also elephants and birds, but in a different form of design and arrangement. Within the borders, the figure of the Hindu deity Shiva is present all over the brocade stole. The pattern of Shiva is upside down from the top of the stole to its horizontal mid-point. He is in a lotus position and there are patterns of tree branches that come with flowers and parakeets.

metadata.subject_terms_2: Textiles Stoles (Clothing) Motifs Siva (Hindu deity) Shawls
metadata.sgcool_label_text: This Benarasi silk brocade carries the extremely unusual motif of Shiva as Yogeshwara, seated as an ascetic upon a tiger skin, holding a trident in one hand, damroo in the other, which a cobra around his shoulders. Each figure is separated by a flowering plant upon which are perched a magpie and a woodpecker. It is a superb example of the fine detail that Benarasi weavers could achieve using multi-coloured threads and a very tight weave.
